articles.title: One small walking adjustment could delay knee surgery for years
articles.summary: A groundbreaking study has found that a simple change in walking style can ease osteoarthritis pain as effectively as medication—without the side effects. By adjusting foot angle, participants reduced knee stress, slowed cartilage damage, and maintained the change for over a year.
articles.content:
Nearly a quarter of people over the age of 40 experience painful osteoarthritis, making it a leading cause of disability in adults. Osteoarthritis degrades joint-cushioning cartilage, and there is currently no way of reversing this damage: the only option is to manage pain with medication, and eventually, joint replacement.

Researchers from the University of Utah, New York University and Stanford University are now demonstrating the potential for another option: gait retraining.

By making a small adjustment to the angle of their foot while walking, participants in a year-long randomized control trial experienced pain relief equivalent to medication. Critically, those participants also showed less knee cartilage degradation over that period as compared to a group that received a placebo treatment.

Published in The Lancet Rheumatologyand co-led by Scott Uhlrich of Utah's John and Marcia Price College of Engineering, these findings come from the first placebo-controlled study to demonstrate the effectiveness of a biomechanical intervention for osteoarthritis.

"We've known that for people with osteoarthritis, higher loads in their knee accelerate progression, and that changing the foot angle can reduce knee load," said Uhlrich, an assistant professor of mechanical engineering. "So the idea of a biomechanical intervention is not new, but there have not been randomized, placebo-controlled studies to show that they're effective."

With support from the National Institutes of Health and other federal agencies, the researchers were specifically looking at patients with mild-to-moderate osteoarthritis in the medial compartment of the knee -- on the inside of the leg -- which tends to bear more weight than the lateral, outside, compartment. This form of osteoarthritis is the most common, but the ideal foot angle for reducing load in the medial side of the knee differs from person to person depending on their natural gait and how it changes when they adopt the new walking pattern.

"Previous trials prescribed the same intervention to all individuals, resulting in some individuals not reducing, or even increasing, their joint loading," Uhlrich said. "We used a personalized approach to selecting each individual's new walking pattern, which improved how much individuals could offload their knee and likely contributed to the positive effect on pain and cartilage that we saw."

In their first two visits, participants received a baseline MRI and practiced walking on a pressure-sensitive treadmill while motion-capture cameras recorded the mechanics of their gait. This allowed the researchers to determine whether turning the patient's toe inward or outward would reduce load more, and whether a 5° or 10° adjustment would be ideal.

This personalized analysis also screened out potential participants who could not benefit from the intervention, as none of the foot angle changes could decrease loading in their knees. These participants were included in previous studies, which may have contributed to those studies' inconclusive pain results.

Moreover, after their initial intake sessions, half of the 68 participants were assigned to a sham treatment group to control for the placebo effect. These participants were prescribed foot angles that were actually identical to their natural gait. Conversely, participants in the intervention group were prescribed the change in foot angle that maximally reduced their knee loading.

Participants from both groups returned to the lab for six weekly training sessions, where they received biofeedback -- vibrations from a device worn on the shin -- that helped them maintain the prescribed foot angle while walking on the lab's treadmill. After the six-week training period, participants were encouraged to practice their new gait for at least 20 minutes a day, to the point where it became natural. Periodic check-in visits showed that participants were adhering to their prescribed foot angle within a degree on average.

After a year, all participants self-reported their experience of knee pain and had a second MRI to quantitatively assess the damage to their knee cartilage.

"The reported decrease in pain over the placebo group was somewhere between what you'd expect from an over-the-counter medication, like ibuprofen, and a narcotic, like oxycontin," Uhlrich said. "With the MRIs, we also saw slower degradation of a marker of cartilage health in the intervention group, which was quite exciting."

Beyond the quantitative measures of effectiveness, participants in the study expressed enthusiasm for both the approach and the results. One participant said: "I don't have to take a drug or wear a device…it's just a part of my body now that will be with me for the rest of my days, so that I'm thrilled with."

Participants' ability to adhere to the intervention over long periods of time is one of its potential advantages.

"Especially for people in their 30's, 40's, or 50's, osteoarthritis could mean decades of pain management before they're recommended for a joint replacement," Uhrlich said. "This intervention could help fill that large treatment gap."

Before this intervention can be clinically deployed, the gait retraining process will need to be streamlined. The motion-capture technique used to make the original foot angle prescription is expensive and time-consuming; the researchers envision this intervention to eventually be prescribed in a physical therapy clinic and retraining can happen while people go for a walk around their neighborhood.

"We and others have developed technology that could be used to both personalize and deliver this intervention in a clinical setting using mobile sensors, like smartphone video and a 'smart shoe'," Uhlrich said. Future studies of this approach are needed before the intervention can be made widely available to the public.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant, evidence-based medical breakthrough offering a non-invasive, drug-free intervention that can reduce osteoarthritis pain and slow cartilage damage, potentially delaying the need for surgery for millions of adults. The study is well-detailed, involves a personalized approach, and has broad implications for public health given the prevalence of osteoarthritis.
articles.personality_title: Simple change in walking style eases knee pain and slows arthritis damage
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Osteoarthritis is a common joint disease that causes pain and worsens with age. It happens when the cartilage that cushions the knee joint breaks down. Right now, people often manage the pain with medicine or surgery, but there is no way to fix the damaged cartilage.

**What happened** – Researchers from three universities tested a new idea: changing the way people walk by adjusting the angle of their foot. In a study lasting one year, 68 people with mild to moderate knee arthritis learned to walk with their toes pointed slightly inward or outward, based on what helped their knee the most. Half of the group made this change, while the other half kept their normal walking style as a comparison. The people who changed their walking reported less pain and had less cartilage damage after a year.

**Impact** – This study is the first to prove that a simple, personalized change in walking can reduce knee pain as much as some medicines, but without side effects. It also slowed down the damage to the knee cartilage, which could delay or reduce the need for surgery. Participants were able to keep this new walking style for over a year, making it a practical long-term solution.

**What's next step** – The current method to find the best foot angle uses special cameras and treadmills, which are expensive and take time. Researchers want to develop easier ways to help people learn this new walking style using smartphones or smart shoes in regular clinics. More studies will be done to make this treatment widely available.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Adjusting how you walk by changing your foot angle can reduce knee arthritis pain and slow joint damage, offering a drug-free way to improve life for many people.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un simple ajustement de la marche réduit la douleur au genou et ralentit l’arthrose
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’arthrose est une maladie courante qui cause des douleurs aux articulations en raison de la dégradation du cartilage du genou. Aujourd’hui, on gère souvent la douleur avec des médicaments ou une chirurgie, mais on ne peut pas réparer le cartilage endommagé.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de trois universités ont testé une nouvelle idée : modifier la façon de marcher en ajustant l’angle du pied. Pendant un an, 68 personnes souffrant d’arthrose légère à modérée ont appris à marcher avec les orteils légèrement tournés vers l’intérieur ou l’extérieur, selon ce qui soulageait le plus leur genou. La moitié a fait ce changement, l’autre moitié a gardé sa façon normale de marcher. Ceux qui ont changé ont ressenti moins de douleur et leur cartilage a moins été endommagé.

**Impact** – C’est la première étude à prouver qu’un simple ajustement personnalisé de la marche peut réduire la douleur au genou autant que certains médicaments, mais sans effets secondaires. Cela ralentit aussi la dégradation du cartilage, ce qui pourrait retarder ou éviter la chirurgie. Les participants ont réussi à garder cette nouvelle façon de marcher pendant plus d’un an, ce qui la rend pratique sur le long terme.

**Prochaine étape** – La méthode actuelle pour trouver l’angle idéal du pied utilise des caméras spéciales et des tapis roulants, ce qui est coûteux et long. Les chercheurs veulent développer des solutions plus simples avec des smartphones ou des chaussures intelligentes, pour que ce traitement soit accessible dans les cliniques. D’autres études sont prévues.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Modifier l’angle du pied en marchant peut réduire la douleur de l’arthrose du genou et ralentir les dégâts, offrant une solution sans médicament pour améliorer la vie de nombreux patients.
articles.personality_title_es: Un simple cambio en la forma de caminar reduce el dolor de rodilla y frena la artritis
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La osteoartritis es una enfermedad común que causa dolor en las articulaciones debido al desgaste del cartílago en la rodilla. Actualmente, las personas suelen manejar el dolor con medicamentos o cirugía, pero no existe forma de reparar el cartílago dañado.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de tres universidades probaron una nueva idea: cambiar la forma de caminar ajustando el ángulo del pie. Durante un año, 68 personas con artritis leve a moderada aprendieron a caminar con los dedos apuntando un poco hacia adentro o hacia afuera, según lo que ayudaba más a su rodilla. La mitad hizo este cambio y la otra mitad mantuvo su forma normal de caminar. Quienes cambiaron reportaron menos dolor y menos daño en el cartílago.

**Impacto** – Este es el primer estudio que demuestra que un simple cambio personalizado en la forma de caminar puede reducir el dolor de rodilla tanto como algunos medicamentos, pero sin efectos secundarios. También frenó el daño al cartílago, lo que podría retrasar o evitar la cirugía. Los participantes mantuvieron este nuevo estilo de caminar por más de un año, haciendo que sea una solución práctica a largo plazo.

**Próximo paso** – El método actual para encontrar el mejor ángulo del pie usa cámaras especiales y cintas de correr, lo que es caro y lento. Los investigadores quieren crear formas más fáciles usando teléfonos inteligentes o zapatos inteligentes para que este tratamiento esté disponible en clínicas. Se harán más estudios.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Cambiar el ángulo del pie al caminar puede reducir el dolor por artritis de rodilla y frenar el daño articular, ofreciendo una forma sin medicamentos para mejorar la vida de muchas personas.

articles.title: Watch a human embryo implant itself — with brute force
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 15 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02627-2Video provides an up-close look at a human embryo plunging into tissue that simulates the uterine lining.
articles.content:
A microscopic view of a nine-day-old human embryo shows a protein found in embryonic stem cells in green, developing tissue in magenta and DNA in blue. Credit: Institute for Bioengineering of Catalonia (IBEC)

A time-lapse film offers a glimpse of a hidden milestone of human development: the moment when the newly formed embryo latches onto the uterine lining. Researchers have captured real-time footage of an embryo pulling on a high-fidelity replica of the lining to bury itself inside, effectively remodelling its new home.

The team reports its findings today in Science Advances1.

Hidden figures

The authors were inspired to simulate the implantation process because the actual events are so difficult to capture. “It’s very inaccessible because it’s all happening inside the mother,” says co-author Samuel Ojosnegros, a bioengineer at the Institute for Bioengineering of Catalonia (IBEC) in Barcelona, Spain. “It’s such an important process for human reproduction, but at the same time, we don’t have the technology to study it.”

A human embryo contracts itself to minimize its exposure to the outside environment.Credit: Institute for Bioengineering of Catalonia (IBEC)

Although previous studies have investigated how human embryos interact with glass, the embryo can’t penetrate this material as it does real human tissue. So the team set out to create a more lifelike mock-up, devising a faux uterine lining from a gel rich in collagen and proteins that are crucial for embryonic development.

To shoot their stop-motion film, researchers placed human embryos donated by a local hospital near the gel. As the embryo attached to the ‘uterus’, the team used a microscope to capture an image about every 20 minutes for 16–24 hours, and then stitched the stills together.

Co-author Amélie Godeau, a biomechanics researcher at IBEC, was shocked to see how quickly the embryo burrowed down into the gel. “My first reflex was to think my experiment had gone wrong and there was some drift in the microscope,” Godeau says. By contrast, the team found that mouse embryos adhere to the surface of the uterus rather than embedding itself inside.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding a crucial stage of human reproduction by capturing real-time footage of embryo implantation using a novel simulation method. This advancement provides valuable insights that can impact fertility research and reproductive health on a broad scale. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful discovery with potential health benefits.
articles.personality_title: Scientists capture real-time video of human embryo embedding into uterine tissue
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long struggled to observe how a human embryo attaches itself to the uterus because this process happens deep inside the body and is very hard to see.

**What happened** – Researchers at the Institute for Bioengineering of Catalonia in Spain created a special gel that mimics the lining of the uterus. They placed donated human embryos next to this gel and used a microscope to take pictures every 20 minutes over about a day. These images were combined into a time-lapse video showing the embryo pulling itself into the gel, similar to how it would embed in a real uterus.

**Impact** – This is the first time scientists have seen how a human embryo actively burrows into tissue, rather than just sticking to the surface. Understanding this step better could help improve fertility treatments and give doctors new information about early pregnancy.

**What's next step** – Researchers plan to study more embryos and refine their uterine gel model to explore how different factors affect implantation. This could lead to new ways to support healthy pregnancies or address fertility problems.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time, scientists have filmed a human embryo using force to embed itself into tissue, shedding light on a key moment in early development.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques filment en temps réel un embryon humain s’implantant dans un tissu utérin
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques ont longtemps eu du mal à observer comment un embryon humain s’attache à l’utérus, car ce processus se déroule profondément dans le corps et est très difficile à voir.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Institut de Bioingénierie de Catalogne en Espagne ont créé un gel spécial qui imite la paroi de l’utérus. Ils ont placé des embryons humains donnés à côté de ce gel et ont utilisé un microscope pour prendre des photos toutes les 20 minutes pendant environ une journée. Ces images ont été assemblées en une vidéo en accéléré montrant l’embryon s’enfonçant dans le gel, comme il le ferait dans un vrai utérus.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que les scientifiques voient un embryon humain s’enfouir activement dans un tissu, plutôt que de simplement y adhérer. Mieux comprendre cette étape pourrait aider à améliorer les traitements contre l’infertilité et donner de nouvelles informations sur les débuts de la grossesse.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs prévoient d’étudier davantage d’embryons et d’améliorer leur modèle de gel utérin pour explorer comment différents facteurs influencent l’implantation. Cela pourrait conduire à de nouvelles méthodes pour soutenir des grossesses saines ou traiter les problèmes de fertilité.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Pour la première fois, des scientifiques ont filmé un embryon humain utilisant la force pour s’implanter dans un tissu, éclairant un moment clé du développement précoce.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos capturan en video en tiempo real un embrión humano implantándose en tejido uterino
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han tenido dificultades para observar cómo un embrión humano se adhiere al útero porque este proceso ocurre dentro del cuerpo y es muy difícil de ver.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores del Instituto de Bioingeniería de Cataluña en España crearon un gel especial que imita el revestimiento del útero. Colocaron embriones humanos donados junto a este gel y usaron un microscopio para tomar fotos cada 20 minutos durante cerca de un día. Estas imágenes se unieron para formar un video en lapso de tiempo que muestra cómo el embrión se introduce en el gel, como lo haría en un útero real.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que los científicos ven a un embrión humano hundirse activamente en un tejido, en lugar de solo adherirse a la superficie. Entender mejor este paso podría ayudar a mejorar los tratamientos de fertilidad y aportar nueva información sobre el inicio del embarazo.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean estudiar más embriones y perfeccionar su modelo de gel uterino para explorar cómo diferentes factores afectan la implantación. Esto podría conducir a nuevas formas de apoyar embarazos saludables o resolver problemas de fertilidad.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Por primera vez, científicos filmaron a un embrión humano usando fuerza para incrustarse en tejido, revelando un momento clave del desarrollo temprano.

articles.title: Cancelling mRNA studies is the highest irresponsibility
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 15 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02612-9The rest of the world is not following the US government’s dangerous path, and will stick with the technology that helped the world out of the COVID-19 pandemic.
articles.content:
The rest of the world is not following the US government’s dangerous path, and will stick with the technology that helped the world out of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Italian street artist Harry Greb’s mural in front of Rome’s health ministry celebrating the arrival of COVID-19 vaccines in 2021.Credit: Marilla Sicilia/Archivio Marilla Sicilia/Mondadori Portfolio/Getty

A technology that played a key part in saving millions of lives during the COVID-19 pandemic1 should be feted to the skies. Instead, US health secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr announced last week that the US federal government is terminating 22 grants worth nearly US$500 million for projects researching messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccines.

This is the technology that, in his first term (2017–21), US President Donald Trump included in Operation Warp Speed: the federal government’s $18-billion programme to procure COVID-19 vaccines for US populations in record time2. It is also the technology that is showing potential for treating cancers3, autoimmune diseases and inherited conditions such as sickle cell disease. But now, in a statement accompanying the grant cancellations, Kennedy stated that “these vaccines fail to protect effectively against upper respiratory infections like COVID and flu”. And in an article for The Washington Post, Jay Bhattacharya, director of the US National Institutes of Health, wrote that mRNA technology “failed to earn the public’s trust”, which fuelled vaccine hesitancy.

Trump’s chief science adviser faces a storm of criticism: what's next?

Shock and disbelief does not even begin to describe the reaction from mRNA and public-health researchers. The Alliance for mRNA Medicines, which represents companies and universities, said in a statement: “Secretary Kennedy’s unscientific and misguided vilification of mRNA technology and cancellation of grants is the epitome of cutting off your nose to spite your face.”

True words. Yet this announcement is not unexpected. Kennedy’s views on vaccination are well known, and outside the research consensus. As Nature’s news team and others have reported for months, the Trump administration is busy removing independent specialists and replacing them with political appointments in many cases. This has happened in science and public-policy domains including health, economic statistics and the environment.

Often, where the world’s one-time science superpower has led, others have keenly followed. But not in this instance. There is no queue of countries lining up to adopt the Kennedy doctrine. One reason is that most countries appreciate that the mRNA manufacturing platform can be repurposed for different uses. Predicting how many vaccines to stockpile for an emergency has always been a huge headache for governments, as has been the cost of keeping manufacturing facilities open when they are not in use. With mRNA, when a platform isn’t being used to make vaccines, it will not just sit idle, racking up costs, but instead has the potential to be used to manufacture other therapeutics.

At the same time, mRNA technology is on its way to unlocking vaccine self-sufficiency in health emergencies for low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). During the COVID-19 pandemic, the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations-backed Medicines Patent Pool, which seeks licences to use patented technologies, established a plan to transfer mRNA technology to LMICs. It was a direct response to people dying because their governments were unable to procure expensive vaccines made abroad, with richer countries hoarding supplies. Fifteen countries are on a programme to establish and eventually scale up manufacturing to the required quality, quantity, safety and efficacy standards. The plan, which is being implemented by Afrigen Biologics and Vaccines, a company based in Cape Town, South Africa, is working. It’s a real win and an excellent model for how to share technologies so that everyone benefits.

Trump order gives political appointees vast powers over research grants

All decisions on new technologies involve a risk–benefit calculation, and no medical technology is entirely risk-free. However, studies assessing safety and efficacy data confirm, overwhelmingly, that the benefits of mRNA vaccines outweigh the risks. These risks must continue to be studied, as must the reasons for vaccine hesitancy.

But public confidence in vaccines isn’t boosted by governments cancelling science. Moreover, removing funding for a cutting-edge technology that has saved lives will leave people less protected when the next pandemic strikes. It is irresponsible and will slow global progress. US scientists, funded by national grants, have been hugely involved in international collaborations in mRNA research.

Until now, it has been impossible to imagine mRNA research without the United States. Seminal work on the technology has been the product of US laboratories, including Paul Krieg and Douglas Melton’s efforts to synthesize mRNA in the lab in the 1980s, and Katalin Karikó and Drew Weissman’s Nobel-prizewinning work on how cells recognize and respond to different forms of mRNA. And when it comes to funding, so far, the United States has been the only government that can match pharmaceutical companies for mRNA investments. This is why the enormity of the US decision cannot be overstated.

Countries outside the United States are right to choose a different course. They must now increase their investments in mRNA studies, including boosting funding for the WHO’s work on mRNA technology transfer. The pandemic might seem like a distant memory to some, but we must never, ever, forget that millions are alive today, or in better health, because of this life-saving technology.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the global commitment to continuing mRNA vaccine research and technology transfer to low- and middle-income countries despite the US government's cancellation of funding. This ongoing international effort supports vaccine self-sufficiency, pandemic preparedness, and potential treatments for serious diseases, representing a significant positive impact on global health.
articles.personality_title: World keeps supporting mRNA vaccine research despite US funding cuts
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – mRNA vaccine technology helped save millions of lives during the COVID-19 pandemic. It was strongly supported by the US government during President Trump’s term, especially through a program called Operation Warp Speed, which funded fast vaccine development.

**What happened** – In August 2025, the US government decided to stop funding 22 research projects on mRNA vaccines, cutting nearly $500 million in grants. This decision was announced by US Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who criticized the vaccines’ effectiveness. Many scientists and companies disagreed strongly with this move.

**Impact** – Despite the US decision, many countries continue to invest in mRNA technology. This includes efforts to help low- and middle-income countries make their own vaccines. For example, a program led by Afrigen Biologics in South Africa is teaching these countries how to produce mRNA vaccines locally. This helps them prepare for future health crises and reduces dependence on expensive imports.

**What's next step** – Other countries and organizations like the World Health Organization (WHO) plan to increase funding and support for mRNA research and technology sharing. This will help improve vaccine availability worldwide and encourage new treatments for diseases like cancer and sickle cell.

**One-sentence takeaway** – While the US cuts mRNA vaccine research funding, the rest of the world continues to back this important technology to improve global health and prepare for future pandemics.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le monde continue de soutenir la recherche sur les vaccins à ARN messager malgré les coupes budgétaires américaines
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La technologie des vaccins à ARN messager a permis de sauver des millions de vies pendant la pandémie de COVID-19. Elle a été fortement soutenue par le gouvernement américain sous la présidence de Trump, notamment grâce au programme Operation Warp Speed, qui finançait le développement rapide des vaccins.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En août 2025, le gouvernement américain a décidé d’arrêter de financer 22 projets de recherche sur les vaccins à ARN messager, supprimant près de 500 millions de dollars de subventions. Cette décision a été annoncée par le secrétaire à la Santé Robert F. Kennedy Jr., qui a critiqué l’efficacité des vaccins. Beaucoup de scientifiques et d’entreprises ont fortement désapprouvé ce choix.

**Impact** – Malgré cette décision américaine, de nombreux pays continuent d’investir dans la technologie ARN messager. Cela inclut des efforts pour aider les pays à revenu faible et moyen à fabriquer leurs propres vaccins. Par exemple, un programme dirigé par Afrigen Biologics en Afrique du Sud apprend à ces pays à produire localement des vaccins à ARN messager. Cela les aide à mieux se préparer aux futures crises sanitaires et réduit leur dépendance aux importations coûteuses.

**Prochaines étapes** – D’autres pays et organisations comme l’Organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS) prévoient d’augmenter le financement et le soutien pour la recherche sur l’ARN messager et le partage de cette technologie. Cela améliorera la disponibilité des vaccins dans le monde et encouragera le développement de nouveaux traitements pour des maladies comme le cancer et la drépanocytose.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Alors que les États-Unis réduisent le financement de la recherche sur les vaccins à ARN messager, le reste du monde continue de soutenir cette technologie essentielle pour la santé mondiale et la préparation aux futures pandémies.
articles.personality_title_es: El mundo sigue apoyando la investigación de vacunas de ARN mensajero pese a recortes de EE.UU.
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La tecnología de vacunas de ARN mensajero ayudó a salvar millones de vidas durante la pandemia de COVID-19. Fue apoyada fuertemente por el gobierno estadounidense durante la presidencia de Trump, especialmente a través de un programa llamado Operation Warp Speed, que financió el desarrollo rápido de vacunas.

**Qué pasó** – En agosto de 2025, el gobierno de EE.UU. decidió cancelar la financiación de 22 proyectos de investigación sobre vacunas de ARN mensajero, eliminando casi 500 millones de dólares en subvenciones. Esta decisión fue anunciada por el secretario de Salud, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., quien criticó la efectividad de las vacunas. Muchos científicos y empresas estuvieron en fuerte desacuerdo.

**Impacto** – A pesar de la decisión estadounidense, muchos países continúan invirtiendo en tecnología de ARN mensajero. Esto incluye esfuerzos para ayudar a países de ingresos bajos y medios a fabricar sus propias vacunas. Por ejemplo, un programa liderado por Afrigen Biologics en Sudáfrica está enseñando a estos países a producir vacunas de ARN mensajero localmente. Esto les ayuda a prepararse mejor para futuras crisis de salud y reduce la dependencia de importaciones costosas.

**Próximo paso** – Otros países y organizaciones como la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS) planean aumentar la financiación y el apoyo para la investigación y el intercambio de tecnología de ARN mensajero.
